title: Introduction to Web APIs
content: Web APIs (Application Programming Interfaces) allow different software applications to communicate over the web. They enable access to services, data, and functionality from servers or third-party platforms.
questions: What is a Web API?
Difference between REST and SOAP APIs?
Why are APIs important in web development?

title: Types of Web APIs
content: Web APIs can be categorized into REST APIs, SOAP APIs, GraphQL APIs, and WebSocket APIs.
questions: What is a REST API?
What is SOAP API?
Difference between REST and GraphQL?

title: RESTful API Concepts
content: REST (Representational State Transfer) is an architectural style using HTTP methods: GET, POST, PUT, DELETE. REST APIs are stateless and resource-based.
questions: Explain REST principles.
What are HTTP methods and their purposes?
What is statelessness in REST?

title: HTTP Methods
content: Common HTTP methods for Web APIs include GET (retrieve data), POST (create data), PUT/PATCH (update data), DELETE (remove data).
questions: Difference between PUT and PATCH?
When to use GET vs POST?
What is idempotency in HTTP methods?

title: HTTP Status Codes
content: HTTP status codes indicate the result of a request. Common ones include 200 (OK), 201 (Created), 400 (Bad Request), 401 (Unauthorized), 404 (Not Found), 500 (Server Error).
questions: What does HTTP 404 mean?
Difference between 200 and 201 status codes?
How to handle errors in APIs?

title: API Endpoints and URLs
content: API endpoints are specific URLs where API requests are sent. They define the resource being accessed and the action to perform.
questions: What is an API endpoint?
Difference between base URL and endpoint?
How to structure RESTful URLs?

title: Request Headers and Parameters
content: Request headers send metadata like Content-Type, Authorization. Query parameters filter or customize requests. Path parameters are part of the endpoint URL.
questions: Difference between headers, query, and path parameters?
How to send Authorization token in headers?
What is Content-Type?

title: JSON & XML Data Formats
content: APIs commonly use JSON for data exchange, and sometimes XML. JSON is lightweight and widely used in modern web development.
questions: Difference between JSON and XML?
How to parse JSON in JavaScript?
How to convert objects to JSON?

title: AJAX & Fetch API
content: AJAX and Fetch API allow asynchronous HTTP requests from the browser. Fetch uses Promises for handling requests and responses.
questions: How to make a GET request using Fetch?
Difference between Fetch and XMLHttpRequest?
How to handle errors in Fetch API?

title: Asynchronous JavaScript & Promises
content: APIs require asynchronous calls. Promises, async/await are used to handle asynchronous requests in JavaScript.
questions: Difference between Promises and async/await?
How to handle multiple API requests simultaneously?
What is a Promise chain?

title: Authentication & Authorization
content: APIs often require authentication using API keys, OAuth, JWT tokens. Authorization controls what resources the user can access.
questions: Difference between authentication and authorization?
How to use API keys?
What is JWT and how is it used?

title: Rate Limiting & CORS
content: Rate limiting restricts how many API requests a client can make in a given time. CORS (Cross-Origin Resource Sharing) controls which domains can access the API.
questions: What is CORS and why is it needed?
How to handle CORS errors?
What is API rate limiting?

title: REST API Testing Tools
content: Tools like Postman, Insomnia, and curl help test API endpoints, send requests, and view responses.
questions: What is Postman and how to use it?
Difference between manual testing and automated testing of APIs?
How to test GET, POST, PUT, DELETE requests?

title: Versioning & Documentation
content: APIs often have versions (v1, v2) to maintain backward compatibility. Documentation helps developers understand endpoints, parameters, and responses.
questions: Why version an API?
What is OpenAPI/Swagger?
How to read API documentation?

title: Advanced Web API Topics
content: Advanced topics include GraphQL, WebSockets for real-time communication, API caching, pagination, rate limiting, and securing APIs.
questions: What is GraphQL and how is it different from REST?
How to implement pagination in API responses?
What is API caching and why is it important?

title: End-to-End Web API Guide
content: This guide covers all aspects of Web APIs: fundamentals, HTTP methods, authentication, asynchronous JavaScript, testing, and advanced topics for real-world applications.
questions: Create a REST API endpoint and fetch data using JavaScript.
Secure an API using JWT authentication.
